result.execSummary:
The defendant Perry J Zimmermann was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Misdemeanor, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
*Pay costs and surcharges. 
*Pay DNA Surcharge.
*If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Perry J Zimmermann

records.addlTxt:
Count 1:  Dismissed and Read In
Count 2:  Sentence Withheld and Placed on Probation

Defendant Perry J Zimmermann in court.  Attorney Jared Redfield in court for Perry J Zimmermann.  Attorney Kelly A Cassidy in court for State of Wisconsin. 
Cases heard at this time are 21CF-515, 21CM-367, 21CT-244 and 22CF-258.

9:11 AM Court calls cases.
Atty Cassidy states appearances.

Prior to going on the record, parties discussed a document filed in 21CF-515. Court was presented with the document this morning, has not read it. 
Atty Redfield states it is fine that the Court doesn't have to read it, it is not as relevant of a document due to the joint recommendation of the parties.
Defendant understands this conversation and has no questions, is good with proceeding today with the parameters described.

Plea Questionnaire/Agreement filed.
Prosecutor states plea agreement.
21CT-244: Defendant will plead to Count 2. Count 1 will be dismissed. 
21CF-515: Defendant will plead to Count 2 and Count 4. Count 1 will be dismissed. Count 3 will be dismissed and read in. 
22CF-258: Defendant will plead to Count 2. Count 1 will be dismissed and read in. 
21CM-367: Dismissed and read in.

Attorney for defendant concurs with agreement stated.
Defendant concurs.

Defendant enters a plea of: 
21CT-244: Count 2: No Contest.
21CF-515: Count 2: No Contest.
21CF-515: Count 4: No Contest.
22CF-258: Count 2: No Contest.

Amended Information has been filed in 22CF-258.

Court questions defendant regarding plea questionnaire, waiver of constitutional rights and understandings.
Court advises defendant of elements the state must prove for the charge.
Court questions attorney Redfield for the defendant.
Court finds defendant's plea is freely, voluntarily, knowingly, and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charges.
Defendant agrees there are previous convictions.

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charges.
Court finds the defendant guilty of 21CT-244: Count 2 346.63(1)(b); 21CF-515: Count 2 343.44(1)(b); 21CF-515: Count 4 346.63(1)(b); and 22CF-258: Count 2 946.49(1)(a).
Clerk directed to enter judgment of convictions this date.
21CT-244: Count 1: Dismissed outright.
21CF-515: Count 1: Dismissed outright.
21CF-515: Count 3: Dismissed and Read In.
22CF-258: Count 1: Dismissed and Read In.
21CM-367: Dismissed and Read In.

Atty Cassidy makes sentencing arguments to the court, this is a joint recommendation.
Court questions Atty Cassidy for clarifications.
9:52 AM S.Z. makes a statement.
Atty Redfield makes sentencing arguments to the court. 
Court questions both counsel regarding probation being consecutive to a jail sentence. Both counsel agree that this can be done.
Court questions both counsel regarding why probation is not being considered on the PAC charge. Atty Cassidy replies. Atty Redfield replies. Discussions continue.
Defendant addresses the Court prior to sentencing.
Court questions Defendant.

Court has a number of factors to consider to determine sentencing.

BY THE COURT: 
21CF-515:
Count 2:
Pay a fine of $10 plus costs.
60 days to pay or set up payment plan.
Pay DNA Surcharge.
Provide DNA Sample.

21CF-515:
Count 4:
Sentence is Withheld.
Probation for a period of 4 years. 
Conditions:
Serve 8 months jail as a condition of probation.
Huber is granted for work.
Court does not object to electronic monitor.
Should Jail place Defendant on electronic monitor, sober link should be in conjunction with that.
106 days sentence credit, but not to be applied towards the 8 months, this is in the event that Defendant is revoked.
Pay a fine of $3,000 plus costs.
Pay DNA Surcharge.
Participate in AODA Assessment and comply. BAC: .29
Comply with any assessments, treatment and recommendations deemed appropriate by the agent.
Drivers License Revoked for 5 years.
Ignition Interlock Device for 5 years.


21CT-244:
Count 2:
Jail sentence for 120 days.
2 days sentence credit.
Huber is granted for work.
Court does not object to electronic monitor.
Should Jail place Defendant on electronic monitor, sober link should be in conjunction with that.
Run concurrent with 21CF-515.
Pay a fine and costs totaling $4,012.
60 days to pay or set up payment plan.
Ignition Interlock Device for 31 months.
Drivers License Revocation for 31 months.
AODA Assessment and comply with recommendations - BAC: .308


22CF-258:
Count 2:
Sentence is Withheld.
Probation for 24 months.
0 days jail credit.
Conditions:
Comply with conditions as in 21CF-515.
Pay costs and surcharges. 
Pay DNA Surcharge.

Defendant is remanded to the custody of the Sheriff Department.
Pretrial Supervision Status Report from JusticePoint dated 08/29/22

No written waiver has been filed.
Defendant waives right to preliminary hearing. 
Court questions defendant regarding waiver of preliminary hearing. 
Court questions attorney.
Court finds the defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the preliminary hearing. 

BY THE COURT:  On the defendant's waiver of the preliminary hearing, the court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial.

1:36 PM Defendant Perry J Zimmermann in court.    Atty Jared Redfield appears on behalf of the defendant. Attorney Andrew Mutchler in court for State of Wisconsin. 

Attorney/Defendant received a copy of the criminal complaint.
Court informs defendant of the charges and maximum penalties.
Attorney/Defendant waives reading of the complaint.
Atty Redfield states that a preliminary hearing does not need to be held and that a plea hearing is to be set and this case will be dismissed and read in and the parties will stipulate to this plea agreement.
Court informs the defendant of his rights to a preliminary hearing.
Preliminary hearing is being waived.

Court advises defendant of right to counsel/public defender representation.

BY THE COURT:  Bond continued.
Arraignment scheduled for August 30, 2022 at 09:00 am.
Initial Appearance set for June 20, 2022 @ 1:30 p.m. in Br 2
This will be an uncharged read-in per the DA's Office
Comply with terms of all open bonds.

1:00 PM Defendant Perry James Zimmerman appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney Andrew Mutchler in court for State of Wisconsin. Atty Taylor Soule appears on behalf of Defendant.

Court calls case.
Atty Mutchler states appearances.

This is a riverside hearing.

ADA  Mutcher states facts for anticipated charges of felony bailjumping. 
Atty Soule states that this Defendant does not qualify for public defender representation. Defendant is represented by Atty Redfield in another matter.

Court finds probable cause that a crime has been committed and that this defendant committed it.

State requests a signature bond with conditions as stated. 
Atty Soule does not have any objections as to bond.
Hearing scheduled for May 2, 2022 at 01:30 pm.
